xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/"   xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"   xml:lang="en" > <channel rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/dsa.rdf">   <title>Debian Security</title>   <link>http://security.debian.org/</link>   <description> Debian Security Advisories   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T15:37:49+00:00</dc:date>   <items>     <rdf:Seq> <rdf:li <rdf:li resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3171" /> <rdf:li resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3170" /> <rdf:li resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3169" <rdf:li resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3163" /> <rdf:li resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3162" /> <rdf:li resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3161" resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3158" /> <rdf:li resource="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3157" />     </rdf:Seq>   </items> </channel> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3182">   <title>DSA-3182 libssh2 - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3182</link>   <description> <p>Mariusz Ziulek reported that libssh2, a SSH2 client-side library, was reading and using the SSH_MSG_KEXINIT packet without doing sufficient range checks when negotiating a new SSH session with a remote server. A malicious attacker could man in the middle a real server and cause a client using the libssh2 library to crash (denial of service) or otherwise read and use unintended memory areas in this process.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3181">   <title>DSA-3181 xen - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3181</link>   <description> <p>Multiple security issues have been found in the Xen virtualisation solution:</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3177">   <title>DSA-3177 mod-gnutls - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3177</link>   <description> <p>Thomas Klute discovered that in mod-gnutls, an Apache module providing SSL and TLS encryption with GnuTLS, a bug caused the server's client verify mode not to be considered at all, in case the directory's configuration was unset. Clients with invalid certificates were then able to leverage this flaw in order to get access to that directory.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3180">   <title>DSA-3180 libarchive - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3180</link>   <description> <p>Alexander Cherepanov discovered that bsdcpio, an implementation of the <q>cpio</q> program part of the libarchive project, is susceptible to a directory traversal vulnerability via absolute paths.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3179">   <title>DSA-3179 icedove - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3179</link>   <description> <p>Multiple security issues have been found in Icedove, Debian's version of the Mozilla Thunderbird mail and news client: Multiple memory safety errors and implementation errors may lead to the execution of arbitrary code or information disclosure.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3178">   <title>DSA-3178 unace - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3178</link>   <description> <p>Jakub Wilk discovered that unace, an utility to extract, test and view .ace archives, contained an integer overflow leading to a buffer overflow. If a user or automated system were tricked into processing a specially crafted ace archive, an attacker could cause a denial of service (application crash) or, possibly, execute arbitrary code.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3176">   <title>DSA-3176 request-tracker4 - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3176</link>   <description> <p>Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in Request Tracker, an extensible trouble-ticket tracking system. The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures project identifies the following problems:</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-26</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3175">   <title>DSA-3175 kfreebsd-9 - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3175</link>   <description> <p>Mateusz Kocielski and Marek Kroemeke discovered that an integer overflow in IGMP processing may result in denial of service through malformed IGMP packets.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3174">   <title>DSA-3174 iceweasel - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3174</link>   <description> <p>Multiple security issues have been found in Iceweasel, Debian's version of the Mozilla Firefox web browser: Multiple memory safety errors and implementation errors may lead to the execution of arbitrary code or information disclosure.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3173">   <title>DSA-3173 libgtk2-perl - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3173</link>   <description> <p>It was discovered that libgtk2-perl, a Perl interface to the 2.x series of the Gimp Toolkit library, incorrectly frees memory which GTK+ still holds onto and might access later, leading to denial of service (application crash) or, potentially, to arbitrary code execution.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3172">   <title>DSA-3172 cups - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3172</link>   <description> <p>Peter De Wachter discovered that CUPS, the Common UNIX Printing System, did not correctly parse compressed raster files. By submitting a specially crafted raster file, a remote attacker could use this vulnerability to trigger a buffer overflow.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3171">   <title>DSA-3171 samba - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3171</link>   <description> <p>Richard van Eeden of Microsoft Vulnerability Research discovered that Samba, a SMB/CIFS file, print, and login server for Unix, contains a flaw in the netlogon server code which allows remote code execution with root privileges from an unauthenticated connection.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-23</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3170">   <title>DSA-3170 linux - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3170</link>   <description> <p>Several vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel that may lead to a denial of service, information leaks or privilege escalation.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-23</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3169">   <title>DSA-3169 eglibc - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3169</link>   <description> <p>Several vulnerabilities have been fixed in eglibc, Debian's version of the GNU C library:</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-23</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3168">   <title>DSA-3168 ruby-redcloth - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3168</link>   <description> <p>Kousuke Ebihara discovered that redcloth, a Ruby module used to convert Textile markup to HTML, did not properly sanitize its input. This allowed a remote attacker to perform a cross-site scripting attack by injecting arbitrary JavaScript code into the generated HTML.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-22</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3167">   <title>DSA-3167 sudo - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3167</link>   <description> <p>Jakub Wilk reported that sudo, a program designed to provide limited super user privileges to specific users, preserves the TZ variable from a user's environment without any sanitization. A user with sudo access may take advantage of this to exploit bugs in the C library functions which parse the TZ environment variable or to open files that the user would not otherwise be able to open. The later could potentially cause changes in system behavior when reading certain device special files or cause the program run via sudo to block.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-22</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3166">   <title>DSA-3166 e2fsprogs - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3166</link>   <description> <p>Jose Duart of the Google Security Team discovered a buffer overflow in e2fsprogs, a set of utilities for the ext2, ext3, and ext4 file systems. This issue can possibly lead to arbitrary code execution if a malicious device is plugged in, the system is configured to automatically mount it, and the mounting process chooses to run fsck on the device's malicious filesystem.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-22</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3165">   <title>DSA-3165 xdg-utils - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3165</link>   <description> <p>Jiri Horner discovered a way to cause xdg-open, a tool that automatically opens URLs in a user's preferred application, to execute arbitrary commands remotely.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-21</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3164">   <title>DSA-3164 typo3-src - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3164</link>   <description> <p>Pierrick Caillon discovered that the authentication could be bypassed in the Typo 3 content management system. Please refer to the upstream advisory for additional information: <url "https://typo3.org/teams/security/security-bulletins/typo3-core/typo3-core-sa-2015-001/" /></p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-21</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3163">   <title>DSA-3163 libreoffice - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3163</link>   <description> <p>It was discovered that LibreOffice, an office productivity suite, could try to write to invalid memory areas when importing malformed RTF files. This could allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (crash) or arbitrary code execution via crafted RTF files.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-19</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3162">   <title>DSA-3162 bind9 - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3162</link>   <description> <p>Jan-Piet Mens discovered that the BIND DNS server would crash when processing an invalid DNSSEC key rollover, either due to an error on the zone operator's part, or due to interference with network traffic by an attacker. This issue affects configurations with the directives "dnssec-validation auto;" (as enabled in the Debian default configuration) or "dnssec-lookaside auto;".</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-18</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3161">   <title>DSA-3161 dbus - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3161</link>   <description> <p>Simon McVittie discovered a local denial of service flaw in dbus, an asynchronous inter-process communication system. On systems with systemd-style service activation, dbus-daemon does not prevent forged ActivationFailure messages from non-root processes. A malicious local user could use this flaw to trick dbus-daemon into thinking that systemd failed to activate a system service, resulting in an error reply back to the requester.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-11</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3160">   <title>DSA-3160 xorg-server - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3160</link>   <description> <p>Olivier Fourdan discovered that missing input validation in the Xserver's handling of XkbSetGeometry requests may result in an information leak or denial of service.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-11</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3159">   <title>DSA-3159 ruby1.8 - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3159</link>   <description> <p>It was discovered that the REXML parser, part of the interpreter for the Ruby language, could be coerced into allocating large string objects that could consume all available memory on the system. This could allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (crash).</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-10</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3158">   <title>DSA-3158 unrtf - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3158</link>   <description> <p>Michal Zalewski and Hanno Boeck discovered several vulnerabilities in unrtf, a RTF to other formats converter, leading to a denial of service (application crash) or, potentially, the execution of arbitrary code.</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-09</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3157">   <title>DSA-3157 ruby1.9.1 - security update</title>   <link>https://www.debian.org/security/2015/dsa-3157</link>   <description> <p>Multiple vulnerabilities were discovered in the interpreter for the Ruby language:</p>   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-09</dc:date> </item> </rdf:RDF>
